little Parlor-Table to Night, and bid me call for't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hah— the Bridegroom has it Sir, who is just gone to Bed, it shall be sent him in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Food.
sp.l: 'Tis very well Sir— your Servant—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Let me see— here is the Watch, I took it up to keep for him— but his sending has inspir'd me with a slidden Stratagem, that will do better than Force, to secure the poor trembling Leticia— who I am sure is dying with her Fears.

div.stage: SCENE changes, to the Bedchamber; Leticia in an Undressing, by the Women at the Table.
Enter to them Sir Feeble Fainwou'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Few.
sp.p: WHat's here? what's here? the prating Women still. Ods bobs, what not in Bed yet? for shame of Love Leticia.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: For shame of Modesty Sir; you wou'd not have me go to Bed before all this Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: What the Women; why they must see you laid, 'tis the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What with a Man? I wou'd not for the World.
Oh Belmou●…, where art thou, with all thy promis'd Aid?

sp.speaker: Dy.
sp.l: Nay Madam, we shou'd see you laid indeed.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: First in my Grave Diana.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Ods bobs, here's a Compact amongst the Women— High Treason against the Bridegroom— therefore Ladies withdraw or adod Ill lock you all in.
sp.stage: [Throws open his Gown, they run all away, he locks the Door.
sp.p: So, so, now we're alone Letioia— off with this foolish Modesty, and Night-Gown, and slide into my Arms,
sp.l: H'e ' my little Puskin— what fly me my Coy Daphne,
Hah— who's that knocks— who's there?—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis I Sir, 'tis I, open the Door presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter, is the House o-fire?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Worse Sir, worse—

div.stage: [He opens the Door, Belmour enters with the Watch in his hand.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: 'Tis Belmour's Voyce!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh Sir, do you know this Watch?

sp.speaker: Sir Feb.
sp.l: This Watch.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ay●… Sir, this Watch

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: This Watch— why prethee, why dost tell me of a Watch, 〈◊〉 Sir Cautio●… Fulbank's Watch, what then, what a Pox dost trouble me with Watches.
sp.stage: Offers to put him out, he returns.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis indeed his Watch Sh●…, and by this Token he has sent for you, to come immediately to his House Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: What a Devil art Mad Francis, or is his Worship Mad, or does he think me Mad— go prethee tell him I'll come to him to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To Morrow Sir, why all our Throats may be cut before to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: What sayst thou, Throats cut?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, the City's up in Arms Sir, and all the Aldermen are met at Guild-Hall; some damnable Plot Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hah— Plot— the Aldermen met at Guild-Hall?— hum— why let 'em meet, Vll not lose this Night to save the Nation.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Wou'd you to bed Sir, when the weighty Affairs of State require your Presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: — Hum— met at Guild hall?— my Cloaths, my Gown again Francis, I'll out— out, what upon my Wedding night? no— I'll in.

div.stage: [Putting on his Gown pausing, pulls it off again.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: For shame Sir, shall the Reverend Council of the City debate without you?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Ay, that's true, that's true, come truss again Francis, truss again— yet now I think on't Francis, prethee run thee to the Hall, and tell 'em 'tis my Wedding-Night, d'ye see Francis; and let fome body give my Voice for—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Adod I cannot tell; up in Arms say you, why, let 'em sight Dog, fight Bean; mun, I'll to Bed— go—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And shall his Majesty's Service and his Safety lie unregarded for a slight Woman Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum, his Majesty!— come, hast Francis, I'll away, and call Ralph, and the Footmen, and bid 'em Arm; each man shoulder his Musket; and advance his Pike— and bring my Artillery Implements quick— and let's away: Pupsey— b●…u'y Pupsey, I'll bring it a fine thing yet before Morning, it may be— let's away; I shall grow fond, and forget the Business of the Nation— come follow me Francis—

div.stage: [Exit Sir Feeble; Belmour runs to Leticia.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now my Leticia, if thou●…e'r didst love!
If ever thou design'st to make me blest—
Without delay sly this Adulterous Bed!

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Why Francis— where are you knave?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I must be gone, lest he suspect us— I'll loose him, and return to thee immediately— get thy self ready—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I will not fail my Love.

lg.l: — Old man forgive me— thou the Agressor art,
Who rudely forc'd the Hand without the Heart.
She cannot from the Paths of Honour rave,
Whose Guide's Religion, and whose End is Love.

div.stage: Scene changes to a wash-House, or out-House.
Enter with Dark-lanthorn Bredwel disguis'd like a Devil, leading Gayman.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Stay here, till I give notice of your coming.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Kind Light, a little of your Aid— now must I be peeping tho my Curiosity should lose me all— hah— Zouns, what's here— a Hovel or a Hog-sty? hum, see the Wickedness of Man, that I should find no time to Swear in, but just when I'm in the Devils Clutches.

div.stage: Enter Pert, as an old Woman with a Staff.

sp.speaker: Old Woman.
sp.l: Good Even to you, fair Sir.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Ha— desend me! if this be she, I must rival the Devil, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.l: Come young Gentleman, dare not you venture?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: He must be as hot as Vesuvius, that do's— I shall never earn my Morning's Present.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.l: What do you fear, a longing Woman Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: The Devil I do— this is a damn'd Preparation to Love.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.p: Why stand you gazing Sir, a Womans Passion is like the Tide, it stays for no man when the Hour is come—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I'm sorry I have took it at the Turning.
I'm sure mine's ebbing out as fast.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.l: Will you not speak Sir— will you not on?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I wou'd fain ask— a civil Question or two first.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.l: You know, too much Curiosity lost Paradice.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Why there's it now.

sp.speaker: Old W.
sp.l: Fortune and Love invite you if you dare follow me.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p:
This is the first thing in Peticoats that ever dar'd me in vain. Were I but sure she were but Humane now— for sundry
Considerations she might down— but I will on—

div.stage: [She goes, he follows; both go out.
SCENE. A Chamber in the Apartment of L. Fulbank.
Enter Old Women follow'd by Gayman in the dark.

sp.l: — Hah, Musick— and Excellent!

lg.l: OH! Love, that stronger art than Wine,
Pleasing Delusion, Witchery divine,
Want to be priz'd above all Wealth,
Disease that has more Joys than Health.
Tho we blaspheme thee in our Pain,
And of thy Tyranny complain,
We all are better'd by thy Reign.
What Reason never can bestow
We to this useful Passion owe.
Love wakes the Dull from slugesh Ease,
And learns a Clown the Art to please.
Humbles the Vain, kindles the Cold,
Makes Misers free, and Cowards bold.
'Tis he reforms the Sot from Drink,
And teaches airy Fops to think
When full brute Appetite is fed,
And choak'd the Glutton lyes, and dead:
Thou new Spirits does dispence,
And fines the gross Delights of Sense.
Vertues unconquerable Aid,
That against Nature can perswade:
And makes a roveing Mind retire
Within the Bounds of just Desire.
Chearer of Age, Youths kind unrest,
And half the Heaven of the Blest.

sp.l: Ah Julia, Julia! if this soft Preparation
Were but to bring me to thy dear Embraces;
What different Motions wou'd surround my Soul,
From what perplex it now.
sp.stage: Enter Nymphs and Shepherds, and dance.
[Then two dance alone. All go out but Pert and a Shepherd.
sp.l: — If these be Divels, they are obliging ones.
I did not care if I ventur'd on that last Female Fiend.

sp.speaker: Man sings.
sp.l: Cease your Wonder, cease your Guess,
Whence arrives your Happiness.
Cease your Wonder, cease your Pain.
Humane Fancy is in vain.

sp.speaker: Chorns.
sp.l: 'Tis enough you once shall find,
Fortune may to Worth be kind;
And Love can leave off being blind.

sp.speaker: Pert sings.
sp.l: You, before you enter here—
On this sacred Ring must swear.
sp.stage: Puts it on his Finger, holds his Hand.
sp.l: By the Figure which is round,
Your Passion constant and profound.
By the Adamantine Stone,
To be fixt to one alone.
By the Lustre which is true,
Ne'er to break your sacred Vow.
Lastly by the Gold that's try'd
For Love all Dangers to abide.

div.stage: They all dance about him, while those same two sing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Once about him let us move,
To confirm him true to Love.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: Twice with mystick turning Feet,
Make him silent and discreet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thrice about him let us tread,
To keep him ever young in Red.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Forget Aminta's proud Disdain.
Tast here, and sigh no more in vain.
The Joy of Love without the Pain.
That God vepenes his former Slights,
And For●… thus your Faith requires.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Forget ;
Then tast, and sigh no more in vain,
The Joy of Love without the Pain.
The Joy of Love without the Pain.

div.stage: [Exeunt all Dancers. Looks on himself and feels about him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What the Devil can all this mean? If there be a Woman in the Case— Sure I have not liv'd so bad a Life, to gain the dull Reputation of so modest a Coxcomb, but that a Female might down with me, without all this Ceremony. Is it care of her Honour?— that cannot be— this Age afford none so nice: nor Fiend, nor Goddess can she be, for these I saw were mortal! No— 'tis a Woman— I am positive. Not young nor handsome, for then Vanity had made her Glory to 'ave been seen. No— sinee 'tis resolved a Woman— she must be old and ugly, and will not bauk my Fancy with her Sight. But baits me more with this essential Beauty.

lg.l: Well— be she young or old, Woman or Devil.
She pays, and I'll endeavour to be civil.

div.stage: The flat Scene of the Hall. After a knocking, Enter Bredwel in his masking Habit, with his Vizard in one Hand and a Light in t'other in haste.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: HAh, knocking so late at at our Gate—

div.stage: (Opens the Door. Enter Sir Feeble drest and arm'd Cap-a-pee with a broad wast Belt stuck round with Pistols, a Helmet, Scarfe, Buffcoat and half Pike.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: How now, how now, what's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Bred:
sp.p: Matter, what is my Lady's innocent Intrigue found out?— Heav'n's Sir what makes you here in this warlike Equipage?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: What makes you in this showing Equipage Sir?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: I have been dancing among some of my Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: And I thought to have been fighting with some of my Friends. Where's Sir Cautious? where's Sir Cautious?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Sir Cautious— Sir, in Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Call him, call him— quickly good Edward.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Sure my Lady's Frollick is betray'd and he comes to make
Mischief. However I'll go and secure Mr. Gayman.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Cautious and Boy with Light.
sp.l: Dick, Pray Sir go to Bed, here's no Thieves; all's still and well.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: This last Nights Misfortune of mine Dick, has kept me waking and methought all Night I heard a kind of a silent Noise. I am still afraid of Thieves, mercy upon me to loose five hundred Ginneys at one clap Dick.— Hah— bless me! What's yonder! Blow the great Horn Dick— Thieves— Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Why what a Pox are you mad? 'Tis I, 'tis I Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: I, who am I? Speak— declare— pronounce.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Your Friend old Feeble Fainwood.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: How, Sir Feeble! At this late Hour, and on his Wedding Night— why what's the matter Sir— is it Peace or War with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: A Mistake— a Mistake— proceed to the Business good Brother, for time you know is precious.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Some strange Catastrophe has happened between him and his Wife to Night, that makes him disturb me thus— come sit good Brother, and to the Business as you say—

div.stage: They sit one at one end of the Table, the other at the other, Dick sets down the Light and goes out— both sit gaping and staring and expecting when either shou'd speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: As soon as you please Sir. Lord how wildly he stares!
He's much disturb'd in's Mind— well Sir let us be brief—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: As brief as you please Sir,— well Brother—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: So Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: How strangely he stares and gapes— some deep Concern!

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Hum— hum—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: I listen to you, advance—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A very distracted Countenance— pray Heaven he be not mad, and a young Wife is able to make any old Fellow mad, that's the Truth on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Sure 'tis something of his Lady— he's so loath to bring it out— I am sorry you are thus disturb'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: No disturbance to serve a Friend—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: I think I am your Friend indeed Sir Cautious, or I wou'd not have been here upon my Wedding Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: His Wedding Night— there lies his Grief poor Heart!
Perhaps she has cuckolded him already—
— Well come Brother— many such things are done—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Done— hum— come out with it Brother— what troubles you to Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Troubles me— why, knows he I am rob'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: I may perhaps restore you to the Rest you've lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: The Rest, why have I lost more since? Why know you then who did it? Oh how I'll be revenged upon the Rascal?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: 'Tis— Jealousie, the old Worm that bites—
Who is it you suspect?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Alas I know not whom to suspect, I wou'd I did; but if you cou'd discover him— I wou'd so swinge him.—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: I know him— what do you take me for a Pinip Sir? I know him— there's your Watch again Sir, I'm your Friend, but no Pimp Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: My Watch, I thank you Sir— but why Pimp Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Oh a very thriving Calling Sir— and I have a young Wife to practice with. I know your Rogues?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A young Wife— 'tis so, his Gentlewoman has been at Hot-Cockles without her Husband, and he's Horn mad upon't. I suspected her being so close in with his Nephew— in a Fit with a Pox—
sp.l: Come come Sir Feeble 'tis many an honest Mans Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: I grant it Sir— but to the Business Sir I came for.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: With all my Soul—

div.stage: [They sit gaping and expecting when either shou'd speak. Enter Bredwel and Gayman at the Door. Bredwel sees them and put Gayman back again.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Hah— Sir Feeble— and Sir Cautious there— what shall I do? For this Way we must pass, and to carry him back wou'd discover my Lady to him, betray all and spoil the Jest— retire Sir, your Life depends upon your being unseen.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Well Sir,— do you not know that I am married Sir?
And this my Wedding Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: And that I long to be in Bed?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Very well Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Very good Sir, and very well Sir— why then what the Devil do I make here Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Patienco Brother— and forward—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Forward— lend me your Hand good Brother— lets feel your Pulse— how has this Night gone with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— this is the oddest Quonundrum— sure he's mad— and yet now I think on't, I have not slept to Night, nor shall I ever sleep again till I have found the Villain that rob'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p:
So— now he weeps— far gone— this laughing
and weeping is a very bad Sign! Come let me lead you to your Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Mad— stark Mad— no— now I'm up 'tis no Matter— pray ease your troubled Mind— I am your Friend— out with it— wllat was it acted? O●… but design'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir. Cau.
sp.p: Be not asham'd— I'm under the same Prema●…ire I doubt, little better than a— but let that pass—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Have you any Proof?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Proof of what, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Of what, why that you'r a Cuckold— Sir a Cuckold if you'll ha't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Cuckold Sir— do ye know what ye say?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: What I say?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: I what you say, can you make this out?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: I make it out—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay Sir— if you say it and cannot make it out— you're a—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: What am I Sir? What am I?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A Cuckold as well as my self Sh●…, and I'll sue you for Scandalum Magnatum, I shall recover swinging Damages with a City Jury.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: I know of no such thing Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: No Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Then what wou'd you be at Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: I be at Sir— what wou'd you be at Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— why this is the strangest thing— to see an old Fellow, a Magistrate of the City, the first Night he's marryed forsake his Bride and Bed, and come arm'd Cap-a-pee, like Garganta, to disturb another old Fellow and banter him with a Tale of a Tub; and all to be-cuckold him here— in plain English what's your Business?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Why what the Devils your Businessa and you go to that?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: My Business with whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: With me Sir, with me, what a Pox de ye think I do here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: 'Tis that I wou'd be glad to know Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Here Dick, remember I've brought back your Masters Watch, next time he sends for me o'er Night I'll come to him in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha— I send for you? Go home and sleep
Sir— ad and yo●… keep your Wife wijubg ti si Alittle purpose you'd go near to be 〈◊〉 with 〈◊〉 of Horns

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Roguery— —
Look ye this was the Message I receiv'd—

div.stage: En●… Bredwell to the Door— in a white Sheet like a Ghost

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Now Sir we are two to two, for this Way you must pass or be taken in the Ladys Lodgings— I'll-first adventure out to make you pass the fafer. And that he may not, if possible, fee Sir Cautious, whom I shall fright into a Trance I am sure.
sp.l: And Sir Feeble the Devil's in t if he know him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: A brave kind Fellow this—

div.stage: Enter Bred well stalking on as a Ghost by them.

sp.speaker: Sir Gay.
sp.l: Oh— andone— andone— help help—
I'm dead, I'm dead— I

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: As I could wish—
— Come on thou gastly thing and follow me—

div.stage: Enter Gayman like a Ghost with a Torch—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Oh Lord, oh Lord—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Hah— old Sir Feeble Fainwood— why where the Devil am I?— 'Tis he— and be it where it will I'll fright the old Dotard for couzening my Friend of his Mistress—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Oh guard me— guard me— all ye Poe'rs?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Thou call'st in vain fond W●…otch— for I am Be●…,

lg.l: Whom first thor●… robst of Fame and Life.
And then what dearer was— his Wife—

div.stage: [Goes out shaking his Torch at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Oh Lord— oh Lord!

div.stage: Enter Lady Fulbank in an 〈◊〉 and Pert undrest.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Heav'ns what Noise is this?— So he's got safe out I see— hah what thing art thou—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Stay Madam stay— 〈◊〉 I, 'tis ●…a poor trembling Mortal—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Sir Feeble Fa●…ood— rise— are you both mad?—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: No no— Madam we have seen the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Ay and he was as tall as the Mohnment.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: With Eyes like a Beacon— and a Mouth— Heav'n bless us like London Bridge at a full Tide.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Ay, and rear'd as loud—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Idle Fancys, what makes you from your Bed? And you
Sir from your Bride?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Oh! that's the Business of another Day, a Mistake only Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Away, I'm asham'd to see wise Men so weak, the Fantoms of the Night, or your own Shadows, the Whimseys of the Brain for want of Rest, or perhaps Bredwell your Man— who being wiser than his Master play'd you this Trick to fright you both to Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum— adod and that may be, for the young Knave when he let me in to Night, was drest up for some Waggery—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, 'twas even so sure enough Brother—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Ads bobs but they frighted me at first basely— but I'll home to Pupsey, there may be Roguery, as well as here— Madam I ask your Pardon, I see we're all mistaken.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Ay, Sir Feeble; go home to your Wife.

div.stage: Enter Belmour at the Door, knocks, and enter to him from the House Phillis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: OH are you come Sir, I'll call my Lady down.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh haste, the Minutes fly— leave all behind. And bring Leticia only to my Arms.
— Hah— what Noise is that? 'Tis coming this Way— I tremble with my Fears— hah— Death and the Devil— 'Tis he—
sp.stage: Enter Sir Feeble and his Men arm'd, goes to the Door, knocks.
sp.p: Ay 'tis he— and I'm undone— what shall I do to kill him now? besides the Sin wou'd put me past all Hopes of pardoning.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: A damn'd Rogue to deceive me thus—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hah— see by Heaven Leticia! Oh we are ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Hum— what's here two Women?—

div.stage: Enter Leticia and Phillis softly undre st with a Box.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Where are you my best Wishes? Lord of my Vows— and Charmer of my Soul? Where are you?

sp.speaker: Bill.
sp.l: Oh Heavens!—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum, who's here? My Gentlewoman— she's monstrous kind of the sudden. But whom is't meant to?

sp.speaker: Let
sp.l: Give me your Hand my Love, my Life, my all—
— Alas! where are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum— no, no, this is not to me— I am jilted, couzen'd, Cuckol'd, and so forth—

div.stage: [Groping she takes hold of Sir Feeb.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Oh are you here, indeed you frighted me with your Silence— here take these Jewels and let us hast away.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum— are you thereabouts Mistress, was I sent away with a Sharn-Plot for this!— She can not mean it to me.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Will you not speak— will you not answer me?— do you repent already?— before Injoyment are you cold and false?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hum— before Injoyment— that must be me? Before Injoyment— Ay ay 'tis I— I see a little
sp.l: Prolonging a Womans Joy, sets an Edge upon her Appetite.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What means my Dear? Shall we not haste away?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hast away? there 'tis again— no— 'tis not me she means what at your Tricks and Intrigues already— yes yes I am destin'd a Cuckold—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Say, am I not your Wife; can you deny me?

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.l: Wife! adod 'tis I she means— 'tis I she means—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Oh, Belmour, Belmour!

div.stage: [Sir Fee. starts back from her Hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.l: Hum— what's that— Belmour?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Hah! Sir Feeble!— he would not, Sir, have us'd me thus unkindly.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.p: Oh— I'm glad 'tis no worse— Belmour quoth a; I thought the Ghost was come again.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Why did you not speak, Sir, all this while— my Lady weeps with your Unkindness.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.p: I did but hold my peace to hear how prettily she prattled Love: But fags you are nought to think of a young Fellow— adsbobs you are now.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I only said— he wou'd not have been so unkind to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.p: But what makes ye out at this Hour, and with these Jewels?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Alas Sir, we thought the City was in Arms, and pack't up our things to secure 'em, if there had been a Necessity for Flight. For had they come to Plundring once, they wou'd have begun with the rich Aldermen's Wives, you know Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.l: Adsbobs and so they would— but there was no
Arms— nor Mutiny— where's Francis?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.p: Here Sir— why what a Story you made of a Meeting in the Hall and— Arms and— a— the Divel of any thing was stirring, but a couple of old Fools, that sat gaping and waiting for one anothers Business—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Such a Message was brought me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.p: Brought, thou'rt an Ass Francis— but no more— come, come, lets to Bed.—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: To Bed Sir? what by Day-light— fot that's hasting on— I wou'd not for the World— the Night wou'd hide my Blushes— but the Day— wou'd let me see my self in your Embraces.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee.
sp.l: Embraces, in a Fidlestick, why are we not marry'd?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: 'Tis true Sir, and Time will make me more familiar with you, but yet my virgin Modesty forbids it. I'le to Diana's Chamber, the Night will come again.

sp.speaker: Sir Fee
sp.p: For once you shall prevail; and this Damn'd Jant has pretty well mortified me:— a Pox of your Mutiny Francis— Come I'le conduct thee to Diana, and lock thee in, that I may have thee safe Rogue.—

lg.l: Wee'l give young Wenches leave to whine and blush,
And fly those Blessings which— ●ads bobs they wish.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I. Sir Feeble's House.
div.stage: Enter Lady Fulbank, Gayman fine, gently pulling her back by the Hand; and Ralph meets 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: HOw now Ralph— Let your Lady know I am come to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Oh why this needless Visit—
Your Husbands safe, at least till Evening safe,
Why will you not go back?
And give me one soft Hour, though to torment me.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: You are at Leisure now I thank you Sir,
Last Night when I with all Loves Rhetorick pleaded,
And Heaven knows what last Night might have produc'd,
You were ingage'd! False Man, I do believe it,
And I am satisfi'd you love me not.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Not love you!
Why do I waste my Youth in vain Pursuit,
Neglecting Interest, and despisng Power!
Unheeding, and despising other Beauties.
Why at your Feet is all my Fortune laid,
And why does all my Fate depend on you?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I'll not consider why you play the Fool,
Present me Rings and Bracelets; Why pursue me;
Why watch whole Nights before my senceless Door,
And take such Pains to show your self a Coxcomb—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Oh! why all this?
By all the Powers above! by this dear Hand,
And by this Ring, which on this Hand I place,
On which I've sworn Fidelity to Love;
I never had a Wish or soft Desire
To any other Woman,
Since Julia sway'd the Empire of my Soul!

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Hah, my own Ring I gave him last Night.
— Your Jewel Sir, is rich,
Why do you part with things of so much value
So easily, and so frequently?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: To strengthen the weak Arguments of Love.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: And leave your self undone?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Impossible, if I am blest with Julia.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Love's a thin Dyet, nor will keep out Cold,
You cannot satisfie your Dunning Taylor,
To cry— I am in love!
Tho possible you may your Seamstress.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Does ought about me speak such Poverty?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: I am sorry that it does not, since to maintain this Gallantry, 'tis said you use base means, below a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Who dares but to imagine it's a Rascal, a Slave, below a Beating— what means my Julia?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: No more dissembling, I know your Land is gone— I know each Circumstance of all your wants, therefore— as e'er you hope that I should love you ever, tell me— where 'twas you got this Jewel Sir.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Hah— I hope 'tis no stol'n Goods;
Why on the sudden all this nice Examining?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: You trifle with me, and I'll plead no more.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Stay— why— I bought it Madam—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Where had you Money Sir? you see I am no Stranger to your Poverty.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: This is strange— perhaps it is a Secret.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: So is my love, which shall be kept from you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Stay Julia— your Will shall be obey'd!—
Though I had rather die, than be obedient,
Because I know you'll hate me, when 'tis told.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: By all my Vows, let it be what it will,
It ne'er shall alter me from loving you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I have— of late— been tempted—
With Presents, Jewels, and large Sums of Gold.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Tempted! by whom?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: The Devil, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Defend me Heaven! the Divel?
I hope you have not made a Contract with him?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: No, tho in the shape of Woman it appear'd.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Where met you with it?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: By Magick Art I was conducted— I know not how,
To an inchanted Palace in the Clouds,
Where I was so attended—
Young Dancing— singing Fiends innumerable!

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Imagination all.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: But for the Amorous Devil, the old Proserpine.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Ay she— what said she?—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Not a Word! Heaven be prais'd, she was a silent Devil— but she was laid in a Pavillion, all form'd of gilded Clouds, which hung by Geometry, whither I was convey'd, after much Ceremony, and laid in Bed with her; where much ado, and trembling with my Fears— I forc'd my Arms about her.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: And sure that undeceiv'd him—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But such a Carcase 'twas— deliver me— so rivell'd, lean, and rough— a Canvass Bag of wooden Ladles were a better Bed fellow.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Now tho I know that nothing is more distant than I from such a Monster— yet this angers me.
sp.l: Death cou'd you love me and submit to this?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: 'Twas that first drew me in—
The tempting Hope of means to conquer you,
Wou'd put me upon any dangerous Enterprizer
Were I the Lord of all the Universe,
I am so lost in Love,
For one dear Night to clasp you in my Arms,
I'd lavish all that World— then die with Joy.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: 'S'life after all to seem deform'd, old, ugly—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I knew you would be angry when you heard it.

div.stage: [He pursues her in a submissive posture.
Enter Sir Cautious, Bearjest, Noysey and Bredwel.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: — How, what's here— my Lady with the Spark that courted her last Night— hum— with her again so soon— well this Impudence and Importunity undoes more City Wives than all their unmerciful Finery.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: But Madam—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Oh here's my Husband— you'd best tell him your Story— what makes him here so soon—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Me his Story— I hope he will not tell me he's a mind to Cuckold me!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: A Devil on him, what shall I say to him?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: What— so Excellent at Intrigues, and so Dull at an Excuse?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Yes Madam, I shall tell him—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: — Is my Lady at leisure for a Visit Sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Always to receive your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: With me Sir, wou'd you speak?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: With you Sir, if your Name be Fulbank?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Plain Fulbank, me thinks you might have had a Sir-reverence under your Girdle Sir, I am Honour'd with another Title Sir—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: With many Sir, that very well become you—
I've something to deliver to your Ear.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: So, I'll be hang'd if he do not tell me, I'm a Cuckold now. I see it in his Eyes; my Ear Sir, I'd have you to know I scorn any man's Secrets Sir— for ought I know you may whisper Treason to me Sir. Pox on him, how handsom he is, I hate the sight of the young Stallion.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I wou'd not be uncivil Sir, before all this Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Uncivil— Ay, Ay, 'tis so, he cannot be content to Cuckold me, but he must tell me so too.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But since you'll have it Sir— you are— a Rascal— a most notorious Villain Sir, d'e hear—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do— hear— and am glad 'tis no worse.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Griping as Hell— and as insatiable— worse than a Brokering Jew, not all the twelve Tribes harbours such a damn'd Extortioner.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Pray under favour Sir— who are you?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: One whom thou hast undone—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Hum— I'm glad of that however.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Racking me up to starving Want and Misery,
Then took Advantages to ruin me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: So, and he'd revenge it on my Wife—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Do you not know one Wastall Sir?

div.stage: Enter Ralph with Wine, sets it on a Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Wastall— ha, ha, ha— if you are any Friend to that poor Fellow— you may return and tell him Sir— d'e hear— that the Mortgage of two hundred pound a Year is this Day out, and I'll not bate him an Hour Sir— ha, ha, ha— what do you think to hector civil Magistrates?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Very well Sir, and is this your Consoience?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Conscience— what do you tell me of Conscience? Why what a Noise's here— as if the undoing a young Heir were such a Wonder; ods so l've undone a hundred without half this ado.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I do believe thee— and am come to tell you— I'll be none of that Number— for this Minute I'll go and redeem it— and free my Self from the Hell of your Indentures.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: How redeem it, sure the Devil must help him then!— Stay Sir— stay— Lord Sir what need you put your self to that trouble, your Land is in safe Hands Sir, come come sit down— and let us take a Glass of Wine together Sir—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sir my Service to you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir. Wou'd I cou'd come to speak to Belmour which I dare not do in Publick, least I betray him. I long to be resolv'd where 'twas Sir Feeble was last Night— if it were he— by which I might find out my invisible Mistress.

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Wastall—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Will you please to sit Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I have a little Business Sir— but anon I'll wait on you— your Servant Gentlemen— I'll to Crap the Scriveners.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Do you know this Wasball Sir!—

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: Know him Sir, Ay too well—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: The Worlds well amended with him Captain, since I lost my Money to him and you at the George in White Fryars.

sp.speaker: Noy
sp.p: Ay poor Fellow— he's sometimes up and sometimes down, as the Dice favour him—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Faith and that's pity; but how came he so fine o'th'sudden:
'twas but last Week he borrowed eighteen pence of me on his
Wast Belt to pay his Dinner in an Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Were you so cruel Sir to take it?

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: We are not all one Man●… Children; faith Sir, we are here to Day and gone to Morrow—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: I say 'twas done like a wise Man Sir— but under
Favour Gentlemen this Wastall is a Rascal—

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: A very Rascal Sir, and a most dangerous Fellow— he cullye in your Prent●… and Cashiers to play— which ruins so many o'th'young Fry i'th'City—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Hum— does he so— do hear that Edward?

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: Then he keeps a private Press and prints your Amsterdam and Leyden Libels.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay and makes em too I'll warrant him; a dangerous Fellow—

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: Sometimes he begs for a lam●… Souldier with a wooden Leg.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Sometimes as a blind Man sells Switches in New-market Road.

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: At other times he runs the Country like, a Gipsey— tells
Fortunes and robs Hedges, when he's out of Linnen.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Tells Fortunes too— nay I thought he dealt with the Devil— well Gentlemen you are all wide o'this Matter— for to tell you the Truth— he deals with the Devil Gentlemen— otherwise he could never have redeem'd his Land.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How Sir, the Devil?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: I say the Devil. Heav'n bless every wise Man from the Devil.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: The Devil, sha! there's no such Animal in Nature. I rather think he pads.

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: Oh Sir he has not Courage for that— but he's an admirable Fellow at your Lock.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Lock! My Study Look was pickt— I begin to suspect him—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I saw him once open a Lock with the Bone of a Breast of Mutton, and break an Iron bar asunder with the Eye of a needle.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Prodigious— well I say the Devil still.
sp.p: Who's this talks of the Devil— a Pox of the Devil I say, this last Nights Devil has so haunted me—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Why have you seen it since Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: In Imagination Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How Sir a Devil?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Ay, or a Ghost.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where good Sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ay where? I'd travel a hundred Milo to see a Ghost—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sure Sir 'twas Fancy?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: If 'twere a Fancy, 'twas a strong one, and Ghosts and Fancys are all one, if they can deceive. I tell you— if ever I thought in my Life— I thought I saw a Ghost— Ay and a damnable impudent Ghost too; he said he was a— a Fellow here— they call Belmour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How Sir!

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Well I wou'd give the World to see the Devil, provided he were a civil affable Devil, such an one as Wastalls Acquaintance is—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: He can show him too soon, it may be. I'm sure as civil as he is, he helps him to steal my Gold I doubt— and to be sure— Gentlemen you say he's a Gamester— I desire when he comes anon, that you wou'd propose to sport a Dye or so— and we'll sall to play for a Teaster, or the like— and if he sets any Money— I shall go near to know my own Gold, by some remarkable Pieces amongst it; and if he have it, I'll hang him, and then all his six hundred a Year will be my own which I have in Mortgage.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Let the Captain and I alone to top upon him— mean time Sir I have brought my Musick— to entertain my Mistress with a Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Take your own Methods Sir— they are at Leisure— while we go drink their Healths within. Adod I long for Night, we are not half in kelter, this damn'd Ghost will not out of my Head yet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hah— a Ghost! What can he mean? A Ghost, and Belmour's.
— Sure my good Angel, or my Genius,
In pity of my Love, and of Leticia—
But see Leticia comes, but still attended—
— Remember— oh remember to be true!

div.stage: [Aside to her passing by, goes out.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: I was sick to know with what Christian Patience you bore the Martyrdom of this Night.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: As those condemn'd bear the last Hour of Life.
A short Reprieve I had— and by a kind Mistake.
Diana only was my Bedfellow—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I wish for your Repose you ne'er had seen my Father.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And so do I, I fear he has undone me—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And me, in breaking of his Word with Bredwell—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: — So— as Trincolo says wou'd you were both hang'd for me, for putting me in mind of my Husband. For I have e'en no better Luck than either of you—
sp.l: — Let our two Faces wath your approaching one:
I love young Bredwell and must plead for him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I know his Vertue .
But Pride and Modesty, for .

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Wrong not my Brother so who dyes for you—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Cou'd he so easily see me given away
Without a Sigh at parting?
For all the Day a Calm was in his Eyes,
And unconcern'd he look't and talk't to me.
In dancing never prest my willing Hand,
Nor with a scornful Glance reproacht my Falmood.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Believe me that Dissembling was his Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why should he fear, did not my Father promise him?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Ay that was in his wooing time to me.
But now 'tis all forgotten—

div.stage: After which enter Bearjest and Bredwell.

sp.speaker: L. Fulk.
sp.p: How now Cousin! Is this high piece of Gallantry from you?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ay Madam, I have not travell'd for nothing—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: I find my Cos●…en is resolv'd to conquer, he affails with all his Artillery of Charms; we'll leave him to his Success Madam—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Oh Lord Madam you oblige me— look Ned you had a mind to have a full View of my Mistress, Sir, and— here she is
Go— salute her— look how he stands now, what a sneaking thing is a Fellow who has never travell'd and seen the World!— Madam— this is a very honest Friend of mine, for all he looks so simply.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Come he speaks for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: He Madam, tho he be but a Bankers Prentice Madam; he's as pretty a Fellow of his Inches as any i'th' City— he has made Love in Dancing Schools, and to Ladys of Quality in the middle Gallery, and shall joke ye— and repartee with any Foreman within the Walls— prethee to her— and commend me, I'll give thee a new Point Cravat.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He looks as if he cou'd not speak to me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Not speak to you?— yes Gad Madam and do any thing to you too.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Are you his Advocate Sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: For Want of a better—

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: An Advocate for Love I am;
And bring you such a Message from a Heart—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Meaning mine dear Madam●…

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: That when you hear it, you will pitty it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Or the Devils in her—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Sir I have many Reasons to believe
It is my Fortune you pursue, not Person?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: There's something in that I must confess.
But say what you will Ned—

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: May all the Mischiefs of despairing Love
Fall on me if it be.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That's well enough—

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: No were you born an humble Village Maid,
That fed a Flock, upon the neighbouring Plain;
With all that shining Vertue in your Soul,
By Heaven I wou'd adore you— love you— wed you.
Tho'the gay World were lost by such a Nuptial.
— this— I wou'd do were I my Friend the Squire.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Ay if you were me— you might do what you pleas'd; but I'm of another Mind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Shou'd I consent, my Father is a Man whom Interest sways not Honour, and whatsoever Promises he'as made you, he means to break 'em all, and I am destin'd to another.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How another— his Name, his Name Madam— here's Ned and I fear ne'er a single Man i'th'Nation. What is he?— what is he?—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: A Fop, a Fool, a beaten Ass— a Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What a damn'd Shame's this, that Women shou'd be sacrific'd to Fools, and Fops must run away with Heiresses— whilst we Men of Wit and Parts— dress and dance, and cock, and travel, for nothing but to be ta me Keepers.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But I by Heaven will never be that Victim.
But where my Soul is vow'd 'tis fix't for ever.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Are you resolv'd, are you confirm'd in this?
Oh my Dima speak it o'er again.
Bless me and make me happier than a Monarch

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Hold, hold dear Ned— that's my part I take it.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Your Pardon Sir, I had forgot my self.
— But time is short— what's to be done in this?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Done, I'll enter the House with Fire and Sword d'e see, not that I care this— but I'll not be fob'd off— what do they take me for a Fool— an Ass?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Madam, dare you run the Risk of your Father's Displeasure, and run away with the Man you love?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: With all my Soul—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: That's hearty— and we'll do't— Ned and I here— and I love an Amour with an Adventure in't like Amadis de Gaul— harky Ned— get a Coach and six ready to Night when 'tis dark at the back Gate—

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: And I'll get a Parson ready in my Lodging, to which I have a Key through the Garden by which we may pass unseen.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Good— Mun here's Company—

div.stage: Enter Gayman with his Hat with Money in't, Sir Cautious in a Rage— Sir Feeble, Lady Fulbank, Leticia, Captain Noysey, Belmour.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A hundred Pound lost already! Oh Coxcomb, old Coxcomb, and a wise Coxcomb— to turn Prodigal at my Years, whe ' I was bewitch'd!

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Sho, 'twas a Frolick Sir, I have lost a hundred pound as well as you. My Lady has lost, and your Lady has lost, and the rest— what old Cows will kick sometimes, what's a hundred Pound?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A hundred Pound, why 'tis a Sum Sir— a Sum— why what the Devil did I do with a Box and Dice?—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Why you made a shift to loose Sir? And where's the harm of that? We have lost, and he has won, anon it may be your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay, but he could never do it fairly, that's certain. Three hundred Pound! why how came you to win so ummercifully Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh the Devil will not loose a Gamester of me— you see Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: The Devil!— mark that Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The Rogue has damn'd Luck sure, he has got a Fly—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: And can you have the Conscience to carry away all our Money Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Most assuredly, unless you have the Courage to retrieve it.
I'll set it at a Throw, or any Way, what say you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Ods bobs you young Fellows are too hard for us every Way, and I am engag'd at an old Game with a new Gamester here— who will require all an old Mans Stock.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Come Cousin will you venture a Guinny— Come Mr. Bredwel—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Well if no Body dare venture on me I'll send away my Cash—

div.stage: [They all go to play at the Table but Sir Cau. Sir Feeb. and Gay.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Hum— must it all go?— a rare Sum, if a Man were but sure the Devil wou'd but stand Neuter now—
— Sir I wish I had any thing but ready Money to stake— three hundred Pound— a fine Sum!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: You have Moveables Sir, Goods— Commodities—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: That's all one Sir; that's Moneys worth Sir; but if I had any thing that were worth nothing—

sp.speaker: Gay
sp.p: You wou'd venture it,— I thank Iyou Sir,— I wou'd your Lady were worth nothing—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Why so Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Then I wou'd set all this against that Nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: What set it against my Wife?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Wife Sir, Ay your Wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Hum, my Wife against three hundred pounds?—
What All my Wife Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: All your Wife. Why Sir, some part of her wou'd serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Hum— my Wife— why, if I shou'd loose, he cou'd not have the Impudence to take her—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Well, I find you are not for the Bargain, and so I put up—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Hold Sir— why so hasty— my Wife? no— put up your Money Sir— what loose my Wife, for three hundred pounds!—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Loose her Sir— why she shall be never the worse for my wearing Sir— the old covetous Rogue is considering on't I think— what say you to a Night? I'll set it to a Night— there's none need know it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Hum— a Night!— three hundred pounds for a Night! why what a lavish Whore-master's this: we take Money to marry our Wives, but very seldom part with 'em, and by the Bargain get Money— for a Night say you?— gad if I shou'd take the Rogue at his word, 'twou'd be a pure Jest.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: You are not Mad Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: No, but I'm wise— and that's as good; let me consider—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: What whether you shall be a Cuckold or not?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Or loose three hundred pounds— consider that; a Cuckold— why, 'tis a Word— an empty Sound— 'tis Breath— 'tis Air— 'tis nothing— but three hundred pounds— Lord, what will not three hundred pounds do! You may chance to be a Cuckold for nothing, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: It may be so— but she shall do't discreetly then.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Under favour, you'r an Ass Brother, this is the discreetest way of doing it, I take it.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: But wou'd a wise man expose his Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Why, Cato was a wiser man than I, and he lent his Wife to a young Fellow they call'd Hontens●…, as Story says; and can a wise man have a better President than C●…o

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: I say Cato was an Asa Sir, for obliging any young Rogue of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: But I am of Cato's Mill; wel, a sugle Night you say.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: A 〈◊〉 Night— to have— to hold— pos●…— and so forth at discretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: A Night— I man have her ran and 〈◊〉
Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Safe no doubt in't— but how sound I—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: And for Non-performance, you mast pay me Three hundred puunds, I'll forseit as much it I tell—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Tell?— why make your Three hundred pounds six hundred, and let it be put into the Gazet, if you will man— but is't a Bargain?—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Done— Sir Feeble shall be witness— and there stands my Hat.

div.stage: [Puts down his Hat of Money, and each of 'em take a Box and Dice, and kneet on the Stage, the rest come about 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: — He that comes first to One and thirty wins—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: What are you playing for?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing— but a Trial of Skill between on Old man and a Young— and your Lady sli●…p is to be Judge.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I mall be partial Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Six and five's eleven—

div.stage: [Throws— and pulls the Hat towards him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Cater Tray— Pox of the Dice—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Two fives— one and twenty—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Now Luck— Dubles of slxes— nineteen.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Five and four— ●…itty—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Now if he wins it, I'll swear he has a Fly indeed— 'tis impossible without Doubles of sixes—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Now Fortune shine— and for the future frown.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: — Hum— two sixes—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: How now? what's the Matter you look so like an Ass, what have you lost?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: A Bauble— a Bauble— 'tis not for what I've lost— but because I have not won—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: You look very 〈◊〉 Sir— what think you of Cato now?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: A wise man may have his Failings—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: What has my Husband lost?—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Only a small parcel of Ware that lay dead upon my hands, Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: But I shall improve 'em, Madam, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Well, since 'tis no worse, bring in your fine Dancer
Cousin, you say you brought to entertain your Mistress with

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Sir, You'll take care to see me paid to Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Well Sir— but my Lady you must know Sir, has the common Frailties of her Sex, and will refuse what she even longs for, if perswaded to't by me.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'is not in my Bargain to folicit her Sir, you are to procure her— or three hundred pounds Sir; chuse you whether.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Procure her? with all my Soul Sir; alas, you mistake my honest Meaning, I scorn to be so unjust as not to see you a-bed together; and then agree as well as you can, I have done my part— in order to this Sir— get you but your self conveyed in a Chest to my House, with a Direction upon't for me, and for the rest—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I understand you—

div.stage: Enter Bea. with Dancers. All go out but Sir Cautious.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Ralph get Supper ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Well, I must break my Mind, if possible, to my Lady— but if she should be refractory now— and make me pay Three hundred pounds— why sure she won't have so little Grace— Three hundred pounds sav'd, is Three hundred pounds got— by our account— Cou'd All—

lg.l: Who of this City Priviledge are free,
Hope to be paid for Cuckoldom like me;
Th' unthriving Merchant, whom grey Hair adorns,
Before all Ventures wou'd ensure his Horns;
For thus, while He bus lets spare Rooms to hire,
His Wife rackd Credit keeps his own entire.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I. Sir Cautious his House.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: THe Night is come, Oh my Leticia!
The longing Bridegroom hastens to his Bed;
Whilst she with all the Languishment of Love,
And lad Despa●…, casts her fair Eyes on me,
Which silently implore, I would deliver her.
But how! Ay, there's the Question— hah—
I'll get my self hid in her Bed-Chamber—
And something I will do— may save us yet—
If all my Arts shou'd fail— I'll have recourse
To this— and bear Leticia off by Force.
— But see she comes—

div.stage: Enter Lady Fulbank, Sir Cautious, Sir Feeble, Leticia, Bearjest, Noysey, Gayman. Exit Belmour.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Lights there Ralph,
And my Lady's Coach there—

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Well Sir, remember you have promis'd to grant me my diabolical Request, in shewing me the Devil—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I will not fail you Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant; I hope you'll see no more Ghosts, Sir Feeble.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: No more of that, I beseech you Madam: Prethee Sir Cautious take away your Wife— Madam your Servant—
— Come Lette, Lette; hasten Rogue, hasten to thy Chamber, away, here be the young Wenches coming—

div.stage: Enter Diana, puts on her Hood and Scarse.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: So— they are gone to Bed; and now for Bredwel— the
Coach waits, and I'll take this opportunity.
Father farewel— if you dislike my courst,
Blame the old rigid Customs of your Force.

div.stage: Enter Sir Feeble, Leticia and Phillis.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: AH Phillis! I am fainting with my Fears,
Hast thou no comfort for me?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p:
Why what art doing there— fidle fadling— adod you young Wenches are so loath to come to— but
when your hands in, you have no .

sp.l: Why do you talk so Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Was it an anger'd, at the 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 tum-a-me, I'll undress it,

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: You are so wanton Sir, you make me blush—
I will not go to Bed, unless you to Promise me—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: No bargaining my little Hussey— what you'll tye my hands behind me, will you?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: — What shall I do?— assist me gentle Maid,
Thy Eyes me-thinks puts on a little hope!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take Courage Madam— you guess right— be consident.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: No whispering Gentle woman— and putting Tricks into her Head, that shall not cheat me of another Night— Look on that silly little round Chity-face— look on those smiling roguish●… loving Eyes there— look— look how they laugh, ●…wire and tempt— he rogue— I'll buss 'em there, and here and every where— Ods bobs— away, this is fooling and spoyling of a ma●… Stomach, with a Bi●…here, and a Bit there— to Bed— to Bed—

div.stage: As she is at the Toilet he looks over her shoulder, and sees her Face in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Go you first Sir, I will but stay to say my Prayers, which are that Heaven wou'd deliver me.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Say thy Prayers?— what art thou mad, Prayers upon thy Wedding-night? a short Thanksgiving or so— but Prayers quoth a— 'Sbobs you'll have time enough for that— I doubt—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I am asham'd to undress before you Sir, go to Bed—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: What was it asham'd to shew its little white Foot's, and its little round Bubbys— well I'll go, I'll go— I cannot think on't, no, I cannot—

div.stage: [Going towards the Bed, Belmour comes forth from betme●…n the Gurtains his Coat off, his Shirt bloody, a Dagger in his hand, and his Disguise off.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stand—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Hah—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: and Phil. squeak— Oh Heavons— why is it Belmour?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Go not, to Bed, I guard this Sacred Place,
And the Adulterer dies that enters here.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Oh— why do I shake— sure I'm a Man? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am the wrong'd, the lost, and murder'd Belmour.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: O Lord! it is the same, I saw last Night— oh!— hold thy dread Vengeance— pity me; and hear me— oh! a Parson— a Parson— what shall I do— oh! where shall I hide my self.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'th' utmost Borders of the Earth I'll find thee—
Seas shall not hide thee, nor vast Mountains guard thee.
Even in the depth of Hell, I'll find thee out,
And lash thy filthy and Adulterous Soul—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Oh! I am dead, I'm dead, will no Repentance save me— 'twas that young Eye that tempted me to sin; oh!—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: See fair Seducer, what thou'st made me do,
Look on this bleeding Wound, it reach'd my Heart,
To pluck my dear tormenting Image thence,
When News arriv'd that thou hadst broke thy Vow.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Oh Lord! oh!— I'm glad he's dead tho.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Oh hide that fatal Wound, my tender Heart faints with a Sight so horrid!

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: So she'll clear her self and leave me in the Devil's Clutches.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You've both offended Heav'n, and must repent or dye.

sp.speaker: Sir Feb.
sp.p: Ah— I do confess I was an old Fool— bewitcht with Beauty, besotted with Love, and do repent most heartily.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No, you had rather yet go on in Sin:
Thou wou'dst live on, and be a baffl'd Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Oh, not for the World Sir: I am convinc'd and mortifi'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Maintain her fine, undo thy Peace to please her, and still be Cuckol'd on— believe her— trust her, and be Cuckold still.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: I see my Folly— and my Ages Dotage— and find the Devil was in me— yet spare my Age— ah! spare me to repent.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If thou repent'st, renounce her, fly her sight;—
Shun her bewitching Charms, as thou wouldst Hell;
Those dark eternal Mansions of the dead—
Whither I must descend.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Oh— wou'd he were gone!—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fly— be gone— depart, vanish for ever from her to some more safe and innocent Apartment.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Oh that's very hard!—

div.stage: [He goes back trembling, Belmour follows in with his Dagger up; both go out.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Blest be this kind Release, and yet me-thinks it grieves me to consider how the poor Old man is frighted.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: — He's gone, and lockt himself into his Chamber—
And now my dear Leticia let us flye—

lg.l: Despair till now, did my wild Heart invade,
But pitying Love has the rough Storm allayd.

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Cautious his Garden.
div.stage: Enter two Porters and Rag bearing Gayman in a Chest. Set it down; he comes forth with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: SEt down the Chest behind yon' Hedge of Roses— and then put on those Shapes I have appointed you— and be sure you well-favourd'ly bang both Bearjest and Noysey; since they have a Mind to see the Devil.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.p: Oh Sir leave 'em to us for that, and if we do not play the Devil with 'em, we deserve they shou'd beat us. But Sir we are in Sir Cautious his Garden, will not he sue us for a Trespass?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I'll bear you out; be ready at my Call.
sp.p: — Let me see— I have got no ready Stuff to banter with— but no Matter any Giberish will ferve the Fools— 'tis now about the Hour of ten— but Twelve is my appointed lucky Minute, when all the Blessings that my Soul cou'd wish Shall be resign'd to me.
sp.l: — Hah who's there, Bredwel?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Oh are you come Sir— and can you be so kind to a poor
Youth, to favour his Designs and bless his Days?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Yes, I am ready here with all my Devils, both to secure you your Mistress, and to cudgel your Captain and Squire, for abusing me behind my Back so basely.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: 'Twas most unmanly Sir, and they deserve it— I wonder that they come not?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: How durst you trust her with him?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Because 'tis dangerous to steal a City Heiress, and let the
Thest be his— so the dear Maid be mine—
Hark— sure they come—
— Who's there, Mr. Bearjest?

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Whos's that, Ned?— Well I have brought my Mistress— hast thou got a Parson ready— and a License?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Ay, ay— but where's the Lady?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: In the Coach, with the Captain at the Gate. I came before to see if the Coast be clear.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Ay Sir— but what shall we do— here's Mr. Gayman come on purpose to shew you the Devil, as you desir'd.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Shoh! a Pox of the Devil Man— I can't intend to speak with him now.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How Sir? d'ye think my Devil of so little Quality to suffer an Affront unreveng'd?

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Sir I cry his Devilships Pardon: I did not know his Quality— I protest Sir I love and honour him, but I am now just going to be married Sir, and when that Ceremony's past, I'm ready to go to the Devil as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I have told him your Desire of seeing him, and shou'd you baffle him?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Who I Sir? Pray let his Worship know, I shall be proud of the Honour of his Acquaintance; but Sir my Mistress and the Parson waits in Neds Chamber.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: If all the World wait Sir, the Prince of Hell will stay for no Man.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Oh Sir rather then the Prince of the Infernals shall be affronted, I'll conduct the Lady up, and entertain her till you come Sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Nay I have a great Mind to kiss his— Paw Sir, but I cou'd wish you'd shew him me by Day-light Sir.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: The Prince of Darkness does abhor the Light. But Sir I will for once allow your Friend the Captain to keep you Company.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm much oblig'd to you Sir, oh Captain—

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: — Haste Dear; the Parson waits,
To finish what the Pow'rs design'd above.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Sure nothing is so bold as Maids in Love!

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: Pshoh! he conjure— he can fly as soon.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Gentlemen you must be sure to confine your selves to this
Circle, and have a Care you neither swear, nor pray.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray, Sir? I dare say neither of us were ever that Way gifted.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Cease your Horror, cease your Hast.
And calmly as I saw you last,
Appear! Appear!
By thy Pearls and Diamond Rocks,
By thy heavy Money Box.
By thy shining Petticoat,
That hid thy cloven Feet from Note.
By the Veil that hid thy Face,
Which else had frighten'd humane Race.
Appear, that I thy Love may see,
Appear kind Fiends, appear to me!

div.stage: [A Pox of these Rascals why come they not.
Four enter from the four Corners of the Stage to Musick that plays, they dance, and in the Dance, dance round 'em, and kick, pinch, and beat' om.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Oh enough, enough! Good Sir lay 'em and I'll pay the Musick—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I wonder at it— these Spirits are in their Nature kind, and peaceable— and you have basely injur'd some body— and then they will be satisfi'd—

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Oh good Sir take your Cerberuses off— I do confess the Captain here and I have violated your Fame.

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: Abus'd you— and traduc'd you,— and thus we beg your Pardon—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Abus'd me? 'Tis more than I know Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But it seems your Friend the Devil does.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: By this time Bredwel's marry'd.
— Great Pantamogan hold for I am satisfi'd
And thus undo my Charm—
sp.stage: [Takes away the Circle, they run out.
sp.l: — so— the Fools are gone, and now to Julia's Arms

div.stage: She discover'd undrest at her Glass. Sir Cautious undrest.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: BUt why to Night? indeed you're wonderous kind methinks.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Why I don't know— a Wedding is a sort of an Alarm to Love; it calls up every Mans Courage.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Ay but will it come when 'tis call'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: I doubt you'll find it to my Grief—

div.p: — But I think 'tis all one to thee, thou car'st not for my Complement; no, thou'dst rather have a young Fellow.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: I am not us'd to flatter much; if forty Years were taken from your Age, 'twou'd render you something more agreable to my Bed, I must confess.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay, ay, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Yet you may take my Word without an Oath, were you as old as Time, and I were young and gay as April Flow'rs,
sp.l: Which all are fond to gather;
My Beautys all shou'd wither in the Shade,
E'er I'd be worn in a dishonest Bosom.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay but you're wondrous free methinks— sometimes, which gives shrewd Suspicions.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: What, because I can not simper— look demure, and justifiy my Honour when none questions it.
sp.l: — Cry sie, and out upon the naughty Women,
Because they please themselves— and so wou'd I.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: How, wou'd, what cuckold me?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Yes, if it pleas'd me better than Vertue Sir.
But I'll not change my Freedom and my Humour,
To purchase the dull Fame of being Honest.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay but the World, the World—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I value not the Censures of the Crowd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: But I am old.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: That's your Fault Sir, not mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: But being so, if I shou'd be good-natur'd and give thee leave to love discreetly?—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I'd do't without your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Do't— what— cuckold me?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: No, love discreetly Sir, love as I ought, love Honestly.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: What in Love with any Body, but your own Husband?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Yes quoth a— is that your loving as you ought?—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: We can not help our Inclinations Sir,
No more than Time, or Light from coming on—
But I can keep my Vertue Sir intire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: What I'll warrant this is your first Love Gayman?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I'll not deny that Truth, tho even to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau
sp.p: Why in Consideration of my Age and your Youth, I'd bear a Conscience— provided you do things wisely.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Do what thing Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: You know what I mean—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Hah— I hope you wou'd not be a Cuckold Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Why— truly in a civil Way— or so.—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: There is but one Way Sir to make me hate you;
And that wou'd be tame Suffering.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Nay and she be thereabouts, there's no discovering—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: But leave this fond Discourse— and if you must—
Let us to Bed—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p:
Ay, ay— I did but try your Vertue, mun— dost
think I was in earnest?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir here's a Chest directed to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Hum— 'tis Wastall— now does my Heart sail me— a Chest say you?— to me?— so late— I'll warrant it comes from Sir Nicholas Smuggle— some prohibited Goods that he has stoln the Custom of, and cheated his Majesty— well he's an honest Man, bring it in—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: What into my Apartment Sir, a nasty Chest!

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: By all Means— for if the Searchers come— they'l never be so uncivil to ransack thy Lodgings— and we are bound in Christian Charity to do for one another— Some rich Commodities I am sure— and some fine Knick-knack will fall to thy share I'll warrant thee— Pox on him for a young Rogue, how punctual he is!—
— Go my Dear, go to Bed— I'll send Sir Nicholas a Receit for the Chest, and be with thee presently—

div.stage: Gayman peeps out of the Chest, and looks round him wondering—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Hah, where am I? By Heaven my last Nights Vision— 'Tis that inchanted Room and yonder the Alcove! Sure 'twas indeed some Witch, who knowing of my Infidelity— has by Inchantment brought me ther— 'tis so— I am betray'd—
Hah! or was it Julia! That last Night gave me that lone Opporunity— but hark I hear some coming—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Lifting up the Chest Lid. So you are come I see—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Hah— he here, nay then I was deceiv'd, and it was Julia that last Night gave me the dear Assignation.

div.stage: [Aside. Sir Cautious peeps into the Bedchamber.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Within. Come Sir Cautious— I shall fall asleep and then you'll waken me—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay my Dear I'm coming— she's in Bed— I'll go put out the Candle, and then—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Ay I'll warrant you for my Part—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Ay— but you may over-act your Part and spoil all— but Sir I hope you'll use a Christian Conscience in this Business.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Oh doubt not Sir, but I shall do you Reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay Sir, but—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Good Sir no more Cautions, you unlike a fair Gamester will ●…ook me out of half my Night— I am impatient—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Good Lord are you so hasty; if I please you shan't'go at all.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: With all my Soul Sir, pay me three hundred Pound Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Lord Sir you mistake my candid Meaning still. I am content to be a Cuckold Sir— but I wou'd have things done decently, d'ye mind me?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: As decently as a Cuckold can be made Sir.
— But no more Disputes I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: I'm gone— I'm gone— but harky Sir— you'll rise before Day?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Yet again—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: I vanish Sir— but harky— you'll not speak a Word? But let her think 'tis I?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Be gone I say Sir—
I am convinc'd last Night I was with Julia.
Oh Sot— insensible and dull—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: So— the Gandle's out— give me your Hand.

div.stage: Lady Fulbank supposed in Bed. Enter Sir Cautious and Gayman by Dark.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Where are you my Dear?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Where shou'd I be— in Bed, what are you by Dark?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay the Candle went out by Chance.

div.stage: [Gayman signs to him to he gone, he makes grimaces as loath to go, and Exit.
SCENE draws over and represents another Room in the same House.
Enter Parson, Diana, and Pert drest in Diana's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I'll swear Mrs. Pert you look very prettily in my Cloaths; and since you Sir have convinc'd me that this innocent Deceit is not unlawful, I am glad to be the Instrument of advancing Mrs. Pert to a Husband, she already has so just a Claim to.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Since she has so firm a Contract, I pronounce it a lawful
Marriage— but hark they are coming sure—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Pull your Hoods down— and keep your Face from the Light.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Madam I beg your Pardon— I met with a most divellish Adventure,— your Pardon too Mr. Doctor, for making you wait— but the Business is this Sir,— I have a great Mind to lye with this young Gentlewoman to Night, but she swears if I do, the Parson of the Parish shall know it—

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.l: If I do Sir, I shall keep Counsel.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And that's civil Sir,— come lead the Way,
With such a Guide, the Devil's in't, if we can go astray.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p:
NOw cannot I sleep! But am as restless as a Merchant in stormy Weather, that has ventur'd all his Wealth in one Bottom.— Woman is a leakey Vessel— if she should like the Young Rogue now, and they shou'd come to a right Understanding— why then am I a— Wital— that's all, and shall be put in Print at Snow-hill with my Effigies o'th'top like the Sign of Cuckolds Haven— hum— they'r damnable silent— pray Heaven he have not murder'd her, and rob'd her— hum— hark, what s that?— a Noise— he has broke his Covenant with me, and shall forfeit the Money— how loud they are? Ay, ay, the Plots discover'd, what shall I do— Whythe
Devil is not in her sure to be refractory now and peevish, if she be I must pay my Money yet— and that wou d be a damn'd thing— sure they're coming out— I'll retire and harken how 'tis with them.

div.stage: Enter Lady Fulbank undrest— Gayman half undrest upon his Knees, following her, holding her Gown

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Oh! You unkind— what have you made me do?
Unband me false Deceiver— let me loose—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Made her do?— so, so— 'tis done— I'm glad of that—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Can you be angry Julia!
Because I only seiz'd my Right of Love.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: And must my Honour be the Price of it?
Cou'd nothing but my Fame reward your Passion?
— What make me a base Prostitute, a foul Adulteress,
Oh— be gone, be gone— dear Robber of my Quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Oh fearful!—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Oh! Calm your Rage and hear me; if you are so,
You are an innocent Adulteress.
It was the feeble Husband you enjoy'd
In cold Imagination, and no more,
Shyly yon turn'd away— faintly resign'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Hum— did she so—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Till my Excess of Love— betray'd the Cheat.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay, ay that was my Fear—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Away— be gone— I'll never see you more—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: You may as well forbid the Sun to shine.
Not see you more!— Heavens! I before ador'd you
But now I rave! And with my impatient Love,
A thousand mad, and wild Desires are Burning!
I have discover'd now new Worlds of Charms.
And can no longer tamely love and suffer.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: So— I have brought an old House upon my Head.
Intail'd Cuckoldom upon my self.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I'll hear no more— Sir Cautious— where's my Husband?
Why have you left my Honour thus unguarded?

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay, ay, she's well enough pleas'd I fear for all that.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: Base as he is, 'twas he expos'd this Treasure.
Like silly Indians barter'd thee for Trisles.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Oh treacherous Villain!—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Hah— my Husband do this?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: He by Love, he was the kind Procurer,
Contriv'd the Means, and brought me to thy Bed.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: My Husband? My wise Husband!
What Fondness in my Conduct had he seen,
To take so shameful and so base Revenge.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: None— 'twas filthy Avarice seduc'd him to't.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: If he cou'd be so barbarous to expose me,
Cou'd you who lov'd me— be so cruel too!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: What— to possess thee when the Bliss was offer'd,
Possess thee too without a Crime to thee:
Charge not my Soul with so remiss a Flame,
So dull a Sense of Vertue to refuse it.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I am convinc'd the Fault was all my Husbands—
And here I vow— by all things Just and sacred,
To separate for ever from his Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Oh I am not able, to indure it—
Hold— oh hold my dear—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Stand off— I do abhor thee—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: With all my Soul— but do not make rash Vows.
They break my very Heart— regard my Reputation!

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Which you have had such Care of Sir already—
Rise, 'tis in vain you kneel.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau
sp.p: No— I'll never rise again— Alas! Madam I was meerly drawn in, I only thought to sport a Dye or so— I had only an innocent Design to have discover'd whether this Gentleman had stol'n my Gold— that so I might have hang'd him—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: A very Innocent Design indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay Sir, that's all, as I'm an honest, man—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: I've sworn, nor are the Stars more fixt than I

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: How! my Lady and his Worship up?
sp.p: — Madam, a Gentleman, and a Lady below in a Coach knock●… me up, and say they must speak with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: This is strange!— bring 'em up—
Who can it be at this odd time of neither Night nor Day?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Madam, your Vertue, Charity and Friendship to me, has made me trespass on you for my Lives Security, and beg you will protect me— and my Husband—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: So— here's another sad Catastrophe!

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Hah— does Belmou live, is't possible
Believe me Sir, you ever had my Wishes:
And shall not fail of my Protection now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Lady ship.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'm glad thou hast her Harry— but doubt thou durst not own her; nay, dar'st not own thy self.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes Friend, I have my Pardon—
But hark, I think we are pursu'd already—
But now, I fear no force.

div.stage: [A noise of some body coming in.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: However step into my Bed-chamber.

div.stage: Enter Sir Feeble in an Antick manner.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hell shall not hold thee— nor vast Mountains cover thee, but I will find thee out— and lash thy silthy and Adulterous Carcase.

div.stage: [Coming up in a menacing manner to Sir Cau.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: How— lash my silthy Carcase?— I desie●… thee Satan—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: 'Twas thus he said.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Let who's will say it, he lies in's Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: — How! the Ghostly— hush— have a care— for 'twas the Ghost of Belmour— oh! hide that bleeding Wound, it chills my Soul!—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: What bleeding Wound?— Heav'ns are you frantick Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: No— but for want of rest— I shall e'er Morning.
— She's gone— she's gone— she's gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, she's gone, she's gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: — But let her go— so I may never see that dreadful Vision— harky Sir— a Word in your Ear— have a care of marrying a young Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Gau.
sp.l: Ay, but I have married one already.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hast thou? Divorce her— flye her, quick— depart— be gone, she'll Cuckold thee— and still she'll Cuckold thee—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
