sp.l: Ay Brother, but whose fault was that?—
Why, are not you married?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Mum— no Words on't, unless you'll have the Ghost about your Ears; Part with your Wife I say, or else the Devil will part ye.

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: Pray go to Bed Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Yes, for I shall sleep now, I shall ly alone; [Weeps. Ah Fool, old dull besotted Fool— to think she'd love me— 'twas by base means I gain'd her— couzened an honest Gentleman— of Fame and Life—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p:
You did so Sir, but 'tis not past Redress— you may
make that honest Gentleman amends.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Oh wou'd I cou'd, so I gave half my Estate—

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.l: — That Penitence attones with him and Heaven.
— Come forth Leticia, and your injur'd Ghost.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: — HahGhost— another Sight wou'd make me mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Behold me Sir, I have no Terror now.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Hah— who's that Francis?— my Nephew Francis?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Belmour— or Francis— chuse you which you like, and I am either.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Hah, Belmour! and no Ghost?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Belmour— and not your Nephew Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: But art alive? Ods bobs I'm glad on't Sirrah,
— But are you real Belmour?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As sure as I'm no Ghost.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: We all can Witness for him Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Where be the Minstrels, we'll have a Dance— adod we will— ah— art thou there thou couzening little C●…itsface?— a Vengeance on thee— thou madest me an old Doting loving Coxcomb— but I forgive thee— and give thee all thy Jewels, and you your Pardon Sir, so you'll give me mine; for I find you young Knaves will be too hard for us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You are so generous Sir, that 'tis almost with grief I receive the Blessing of Leticia.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: No, no, thou deserv'st her, she wou'd have made an old fond Blockhead of me— and one way or other you wou'd have had her— ods bobs you wou'd—

div.stage: Enter Bearjest, Diana, Pert, Bredwel and Noysey.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.l: Justice Sir, Justice— I have been cheated— abused—
Ass assinated and Ravisht!

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: How my Nephew ravisht!—

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: No Sir, I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: Hum— my Heir marry a Chamber-Maid!

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: Sir, you must know I stole away Mrs. Dy, and brought her to Nea's Chamber here— to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: My Daughter Dy stoln—

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: But I being to go to the Devil a little Sir; whip— what does he, but marrys her himself Sir; and fob'd me off here with my Ladys cast Petticoat—

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.l: Sir, she's a Gentlewoman, and my Sister Sir.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.p: Madam, 'twas a pious Fraud, if it were one, for I was contracted to him before— see here it is—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A plain Case, a plain Case.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Hark'y ' Sir, have you had the Impudence to marry my Daughter Sir?

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and humbly ask your Pardon, and your Blessing—

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: You will ha't, whether I will or not— rise— you are still too hard for us, Come Sir forgive your Nephew—

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will— but all this while you little think the Tribulation I am in, my Lady has forsworn my Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.l: Indeed Sir, the wiser she.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.l: For only performing my Promise to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Feeb.
sp.p: Ay, you show'd her the Difference Sir, you'r a wise man. Come dry your Eyes— and rest your self contented, we are a couple of old Coxcombs: d'e hear Sir Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: I grant it Sir, and if I dye Sir— I bequeath my Lady to you— with my whole Estate— my Nephew has too much already for a Fool.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I thank you Sir— do you consent my Julia?

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: No Sir— you do not like me— a canvass Bag of wooden Ladies were a better Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Cruel Tormentor! oh I cou'd kill my self with Shame and Anger!

sp.speaker: L. Fulb.
sp.p: Come hither Bredwel— witness for my Honour— that I had no Design upon his Person, but that of trying of his Constancy.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.p: Believe me Sir, 'tis true— I feigned a danger near— just as you got to Bed— and I was the kind Devil Sir, that brought the Gold to you.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: And you were one of the Devils that beat me, and the Captain here Sir?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: No truly Sir, those were some I hired— to beat you for abusing me to day—

sp.speaker: Noy.
sp.p: To make you 'mends Sir, I bring you the certain News of the Death of Sir Thomas Gayman your Uncle, who has left you Two thousand pounds a year.—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: I thank you Sir— I heard the news before.

sp.speaker: Sir Cau.
sp.p: How's this; Mr Gayman, my Lady's first Lover? I find Sir Feeble we were a Couple of old Fools indeed, to think at our Age to couzen two lusty young Fellows of their Mistresses; 'tis no wonder that both the Men and the Women have been too hard for us, we are not fit Matches for either, that's the truth on't.

lg.l: That Warrior needs must to his Rival yield,
Who comes with blunted Weapons to the Field.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.stage: Written by a Person of Quality, spoken by Mr. Betterton.

lg.l: LOng have we turn'd the Point of our just Rage I
On the half Wits, and Criticks of the Age.
Oft has the soft, Insipid Sonneteer
In Nice and Flutter, seen his Fop-face here.
Well was the Ignorant Lampooning Pack
Of shatter head Rhi●…●…hipt whipt on Cressey's lack;
But such a trouble Weed is Poetaster,
The lower 'tis cut down, it grows the faster.
Tho Satyr then had such a plenteous Crop,
An After Mach of Coxcombs is come up.
Who not content false Po'try to renew,
By sottish Censures wou'd condemn the true
Let writing like a Gentleman— fine appear,
But must you needs judge too en Cavalier?
These whiffling Critticks, 'tis our Authress fears,
And humbly begs a Tryal by her Peers:
Or let a Pole of Fools her Fate pronounce,
There's no great harm in a good quiet Dunce.
But shield her, Heaven! from the left-handed Blow
Of Airy Blockheads, who pretend to know.
On 〈◊〉 Dulness let her rather split,
Than be Fop-mangl'd under colour of Wit..
Hear me ye Scribling Beaus,—
Why will you in shier Rhime, without one stroke
Of Poetry, Lady's just Disdain provoke,
And address Songs, to whom you never spoke.
In doleful Hymns for dying Fellons fit,
Why do you tax their Eyes, and blame their Wit?
Vnjustly of the Inn'cent you complain,
'Tis Bulkers give, and Tubs must cure your Pain.
Why in Lampoons will you your selves revile?
'Tis true, none else will think it worth their wh ile:
But thus you're hid! oh, 'tis a Politick Fetch:
So some have hang'd themselves, to ease Jack Ketch.
Justly your Friends and Mistresses you blame,
For being so they well deserve the Shame,
'Tis the worst Scandal to have born that Nam
At Poetry of late, and such whose Skill See the late Satyr on Poetry.
Excels your own, you dart a feeble Quill;
Well may you rail at what you Ape so ill.
With vertuous Women, and all Men of Worth,
You're in a state of Mortal War by Birth.
Nature in all her Atome Fights ne'er knew
Two things so opposite as Them and You.
On such your Muse her utmost Fury spends,
They'r slander'd worse than any but your Friends.
More Years may teach you better, the mean while,
If you can't mend your Morals, mend your Stile.
